Award.AwardTitle: English Dialect Features of Indigenous People in North America: A Cross-Continental Investigation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine whether indigenous communities across North America have a shared set of English dialect features. Despite the long history of linguistic research on Native American and Canadian First Nations languages, the English dialect features of such communities are noticeably understudied. English plays an important role in indigenous identity across Native America, even though it is not as well known as some other minority dialects. Moreover, most prior research on Native American English features has lacked a continent-wide perspective or lacked quantitative analysis and insiders' perspectives, thus making it difficult to uncover shared patterns. Dr. Stanford's study helps fill these gaps in knowledge about language behavior in North America, while also empowering Native people as sociolinguistic researchers in their own communities. Specifically, it is hypothesized that many Native American and First Nations people across the continent are linguistically constructing a shared indigenous ethnic identity through a set of contemporary English features, including pitch, rhythm, and grammatical features; these features are most prevalent when Native speakers are interacting with other Native speakers.

This two-year study engages three field sites: (1) Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North/South Dakota, (2) a Sahtu Dene community in Northwest Territories, Canada, and (3) the diverse Native community at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire. Recorded interviews include directed conversation activities and free speech. Pitch and rhythm features are then analyzed with acoustic phonetic methods, and grammatical forms are analyzed quantitatively. Two Native American participants who recently graduated from Dartmouth will conduct field research in their own communities and play key roles in distribution of the new knowledge.

Results will be distributed for both Native and non-Native audiences. Linguists have long promoted the fact that ethnic minority dialects are logical, orderly, linguistic systems, and such information has been valuable for inter-ethnic relations and community self-esteem. But for Native American English, distribution of these socially important perspectives has been much more limited. Dr. Stanford will provide presentations and community discussions, printed materials, and a public interactive website for U.S. reservations and Canadian First Nations communities. In all of these activities, he will coordinate closely with local Native Elders and tribal councils to ensure that the project is beneficial on all sides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This field-based study examined how English is used in Native American and Canadian First Nations communities. In many of these communities, younger generations of speakers have limited access to their heritage languages due to a history of forced cultural and linguistic assimilation. Our project focused on the situation in modern Native communities at the present time. We found that many Native people are creatively and distinctively adapting features of English in ways that express a shared sense of Native ethnic identity, even across disparate communities and locations. Our project also highlights the fact that such Native American dialect features are orderly and systematic, regardless of whether outsiders view them as "non-standard English." The results therefore have implications for sociolinguistics (both theoretical and empirical) as well as practical applications in education and promoting mutual respect and cross-cultural understanding.

Hypothesis:
Prior researchers made valuable progress examining English features in particular Native American and Canadian First Nations communities and regions, typically focusing on grammatical features. Our study took the next step: We hypothesized that certain features (especially intonation and timing) are shared across a wide geographic range and in disparate Native communities.

Fieldwork and data analysis:
Fieldwork was conducted by Native community members (two of our co-investigators), who are participant-observers in their communities. Native co-investigators had central roles of the study, from project design to fieldwork, analysis, presentations, and publications. Fieldwork was conducted in three different Native communities separated by wide distances: (1) Standing Rock Reservation in North/South Dakota, (2) a Dene community in Northwest Territories, Canada, and (3) Native students at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire, who came from diverse tribal and regional backgrounds. The interviews included casual small group settings and also one-on-one interviews between Native people. The recordings were analyzed with acoustic phonetic methods, such as acoustically tracking the pitch of the speakers' voices to uncover intonation patterns, as well as discourse analysis and ethnographic interpretation of conversations and other community observations.

Results: We found a set of distinctive intonation and timing features that our Native analysts perceptually characterized as "Native sounding." This includes a low-to-high pitch contour pattern that typically starts on the stressed syllable of a two-syllable word like Thomas. For example, when a speaker uses this feature, a word like Thomas would have a lower pitch on the stressed syllable (Tho-) and then end with a higher pitch on the second syllable (-mas). We also found several distinctive intonation features at the ends of utterances, such as sentences ending in a mid-level pitch or a high-falling pattern. There is also a timing pattern where syllables tend to have similar duration, unlike other varieties of English where stressed syllables often have the longest duration while unstressed syllables are shorter (bunched together in time).

In our recordings, some speakers used these features frequently, other speakers used them only occasionally, and still others did not use these features at all. Overall, the distinctive "Native-sounding" features were most common in casual settings, especially when speakers were involved in joking and teasing, or in other contexts involving ethnic solidarity, including ironic and/or comedic performances. These results, along with our ethnographic questions and participant-observations, suggest that these distinctive Engish features are being used to express a shared Native identity across disparate tribes and locations.

Products: This project produced a peer-reviewed journal article, a working paper/selected proceedings paper, two academic conference talks, live radio interviews for Native American and Canadian First Nations audiences, including a call-in radio show, local community presentations and interactions, a seminar class for teachers, an educational video, media interviews and reporting in general media outlets, including online discussions among community members, and a general audience magazine article written by the co-investigators.

Conclusion: While many tribes have their own regionalized English features associated with local dialects, slang, and other localized characteristics, our results suggest that certain pitch and timing features are shared across much larger distances. Naturally, Native ethnic identity is highly complex and multifaceted, and language only represents one component of it. We also need to emphasize that not all Native people use these types of English features to express Native identity, and some people may choose to use these features more or less than others, or in different contexts. Nonetheless, our results suggest that many Native people across the continent are constructing a shared sense of Native ethnic identity through this set of English intonation and timing features. In this respect, modern Native speakers are resiliently and creatively using English to construct their own ethnic identity. By identifying and understanding this large-scale sociolinguistic trend, we believe that our project provides valuable research progress as well as the practical benefits of cross-cultural understanding, mutual respect, and educational applications.
